title: Mining Likely Analogical APIs across Thrid Party Libraries via Large Scale Unsupervised API Semantic Embedding
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries
method:
data: API usage embeddings + method name embeddings + documentation embeddings
method: continous skipgram + skip-thought on embeddings and cosine similarity on embeddings
result: outperforms state of art, can find similar documents with lexical gaps. overall recall is not high
authors: Chunyang Chen, Zhenchang Xing, Yang Liu, Kent Ong Long Xiong

title: Learning to Recommend Third-Party Library Migration Opportunities at the API Level
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries
method: migration data + information retrieval + machine learning
result: better accuracy (87%)
authors: Hussein Alrubaye and Mohamed Wiem Mkaouer and Igor Khokhlov and Leon Reznik and Ali Ouni and Jason Mcgoff

title: How Does API Migration Impact Software Quality and Comprehension? An Empirical Study
problem: Find the correlation between API migration and code coupling, cohesion and complexity
method: state-of-art code analysis tools
result: API migration can reduce code coupling and complexity, increase cohesion and readibility
authors: Hussein Alrubaye

title: GUI Migration Using MDE from GWT to Angular 6: An Industrial Case
On the Use of Information Retrieval to Automate the Detection of Library Migartion at the Method Level
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries
method: migration data + customized heap sorting + documentation mining
result: better accuracy (82.1%)
authors: Hussein Alrubaye and Mohamed Wiem Mkaouer and Ali Ouni

title: MigrationMiner: An Automated Detection Tool of Third-Party Java Library Migration at the Method Level
problem: Mine migration instances and relavent code changes
method: a combination of state-of-art tools
result: better accuracy (report 100% but questionable)
authors: Hussein Alrubaye and Mohamed Wiem Mkaouer and Ali Ouni

title: Automating the Detection of Third-Party Java Library Migration at the Function Level
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries
method: migration data + lexical similarity
result: better accuracy (74%)
authors: Hussein Alrubaye and Mohamed Wiem Mkaouer

title: Logging Library Migrations: A Case Study for the Apache Software Foundation Projects
problem: Study the logging library migration phenomenon in Apache projects
method: keyword search + manual inspection
result:
1. Some projects migrate to a new logging library for performance and flexibility
2. Some projects don't migrate because core developers cannot reach consensus
3. Code changes related to migration are usually done by core and experienced developers
authors: Suhas Kabinna and CorPaul Bezemer and Weiyi Shang and  Ahmed E. Hassan

title: ApiWave: Keeping Track of API Popularity and Migration
problem: Keep track of API popularity of 1000 java programs
method: regex match and mine from git

title: Mining Unit Tests for Discovery and Migration of Math APIs
A Study of Library Migrations in Java
problem: Study library dependencies and migrations in Java projects, taking time and category into consideration
method: static code analysis + manual inspection + graph visualization
result:
1. Large projects depend on more libraries than small projects, and a small set of popular libraries are used by most projects
2. Library migrations are occasional, more common in large projects, and can be grouped into different categories with one migration graph for each category
authors: Cedric Teyton and Jean-Remy Falleri and Marc Palyart and Xavier Blanc

title: Automatic Discovery of Function Mappings between Similar Libraries
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries
method: migration data + heuristics
result: accuracy around 50%
authors: Cedric Teyton and Jean-Remy Falleri and Xavier Blanc

title: Mining Library Migration Graphs
problem:
Technical: Mine migration instances from open source data
Empirical: What migrations have been done in the wild and between what libraries?
method: package manager + heuristics
result: several real world migration graphs
authors: Cedric Teyton and Jean-Remy Falleri and Xavier Blanc

title: Cross Library API Recommendation with Web Search Engines
problem: Find semantically similar API mapping between similar libraries (e.g. C#'s equivalent of Java HashMap)
method: search google + return highest tf-idf API
result: work for two cases: Java HashMap and URLConnection
authors: Wujie Zheng and Qirun Zhang and Michael R. Lyu

title: Swing to SWT and back: Patterns for API migration by wrapping
problem:
RQ1: What are the challenges for wrapper implementation?
RQ2: How are design patterns used to address these challenges?
method: case study: Swing and SWT in Java, and two wrapper libraries SwingWT and SWTSwing
result:
Challenges: non-trival mapping multiplicities, mapping varing type hierarchies, varing creation and wiring protocols, inversion of control, correspondance of object identities, etc.
Design patterns: Layered Adaptor, Stateful Adaptor, Delayed Instantiation, Inversion Delegation, Wrapping Identity Map
authors: Thiago Tonelli Bartolomei and Krzysztof Czarnecki and Ralf Lammel

title: Study of an API Migration for Two XML APIs
problem: What are the API differences between similar libraries and can we implement a wrapper between them?
method: case study: implement wrapper between two Java XML libraries
result:
1.  Wrappers need to involve a lot of tuning in order to achieve semantical equivalence in terms of pre- and post-conditions.
2. Full compilance of the wrappers' implementation with the original APIs may be impractical; compilance relevant to some "application of interest" is acheiveable.
authors: Thiago Tonelli Bartolomei and Krzysztof Czarnecki and Ralf Lammel and Tijs van der Storm

title: Do Developers Update their Library Dependencies? - An Empirical Study on the Impact of Security Advisories on Library Migration
problem:
RQ1: To what extent are developers upgrading their library dependencies?
RQ2: What is the response to important awareness mechanisms such as a new release announcement and a security advisory on library updates?
RQ3: Why are developers non responsive to a security advisory?
method:
RQ1: Analyze GitHub Java projects with Maven 
RQ2: Case study
RQ3: Developer survey
result:
1. Developers are reluctant to upgrade their libraries 
2. Projects tend to stick to an old popular version of library
3. Sometimes they are unaware of security alerts, some think its unnecessary to do the upgrade
4. Migration decision is a cost-benefit trade-off
authors: Raula Gaikovina Kula and Daniel M. German and Ali Ouni and Takashi Ishio and Katsuro Inoue

title: Recommending adaptive changes for framework evolution
authors: Barth{\'{e}}l{\'{e}}my Dagenais and  Martin P. Robillard

title: CatchUp!: capturing and replaying refactorings to support API evolution
authors: Johannes Henkel and Amer Diwan

title: Exploring the Use of Automated API Migrating Techniques in Practice: An Experience Report on Android
problem: What are the rael migration practice when updating to a newer library version
method: manual analysis of android documentation and  code changes in Fdroid apps
result:
1. migration through code changes is hard but documentation is undervalued
2. challenges of api migrations lies beyond migration suggestions, and includes many aspects
authors: Maxime Lamoth and Weiyi Shang

title: Towards Smoother Library Migrations: A Look at Vulnerable Dependency Migrations at Function Level for npm JavaScript Packages
problem: Are projects really safe if they do not upgrade their vulnerable dependencies?
method: case study + manual inspection
result: 73.3% of analyzed projects use vulnerable dependencies but they are actually safe from the vulnerablility.
authors: Rodrigo Elizalde Zapata and Raula Gaikovina Kula and Bodin Chinthanet and Takashi Ishio and Kenichi Matsumoto and Akinori Ihara

title: Trusting a Library: A Study of the Latency to Adopt the Latest Maven Release
APIEvolutionMiner: Keeping API Evolution Under Control
Seeking the Ground truth: A Retroactive Study on the Evolution and Migration of Software Libraries
problem: What are the presense and nature of API incompatibilities between different library versions?
method: case study + sophisticated manual inspection
result:
1. API incompatibilities can be very complicated
2. Only a small part of them can be automatically refactored without manual intervention or rule specification
authors: Bradley Cossette and Robert J. Walker

title: Refactoring References for Library Migration
problem:
Empirical: What are the API changes in the wild?
Techinical: Can we refactor dangling references introduced by library API changes?
method:
Empirical: case study, JDiff + manual inspection
Techincal: a prototype tool Trident based on heuristics
result:
Empirical: For each version change, there are 13-28 API changes, require significant developer work to upgrade
Techinical: A qualitative study with developers, they find Trident useful
authors: Puneet Kapur and Bradley Cossette and Robert J. Walker

title: Multi-language Re-documentation to Support a COBOL to Java Migration Project
Satistical Migration of API Usages
DeepAM: Migrate APIs with Multi-modal Sequence to Sequence Learning
Do Context Help in Phrase-Based, Statistical Source Code Migration?
authors: Anh Tuan Nguyen and Zhaopeng Tu and Tien N. Nguyen

title: Mapping API Elements for Code Migration with Vector Representations
Divide-and-Conquer Approach for Multi-phase Statistical Migration for Source Code
Statistical Learning Approach for Mining API Usage Mappings for Code Migration
Lexical Statistical Machine Translation for Language Migration
Inferring Likely Mappings Between APIs
Import2Vec: Learning Embeddings for Software Libraries
problem: Learning embedding vectors for libraries that are often used together
method: Mining library usage at file granularity by extracting import statements + using skip-gram model + empirical analysis to clarify parameter and model choices`
result: The learned embedding can automatically discover contextually similar libraries
authors: Bart Theeten and Frederik Vandeputte and Tom Van Cutsem

title: Which Library Should I Use? A Metric-based Comparison of Software Libraries
Improving Reusability of Software Libraries through Usage Pattern Mining
Search-Based Software Library Recommendation Using Multi-Objective Optimization
Mining Analogical Libraries in Q&A Discussions
problem: Find analogical libraries
method:
dataset: stackoverflow tags as sentences
method: association rule learning to find relationships, nlp to find categories for each tag, then train word embeddings for recommendation
result: Accuracy@1: 80%, Accuracy@5: 60%
authors: Chunyang Chen, Sa Gao, Zhenchang Xing

title: SimilarTech: Automatically Recommend Analogical Libraries across Different Programming Languages
problem: Find functionally similar libraries
method: Mining from a knowledge base built on Stack Overflow
result: 1k accuracy over 80%
authors: Chunyang Chen

title: Automated Library Recommendation
problem: Recommend library based on the library it is already using

title: Investigating diversity and impact of the popularity metrics for ranking software packages
problem: On the relationship between popularity metrics and development activity
method: 195K packages from different repositories
result: Popularity metrics of the Github platform are very strongly correlated(R ¡Ý 0.85) for highly popular packages. Popular packages have high-developmentactivity. However, the number of downloads of a package does not associate withdevelopment activity. Not all the metrics are important for determining popularity ofa software package.

title: A Methodology for Analyzing the Uptake of Software Technologies Among Developers
problem: Why developers choose one technology over another
method: case study on R dataframe packages using social contagoin theory and choice modeling from econometrics
result: High exposure of high quality stackoverflow questions, author proximity, package proximity, fast response to issues is related to higher adoption rates
authors: Yuxing Ma, Audris Mockus, Beth Milhollin, Russel Zaretzki, Randy Bradley and Bogdan Bichescu

title: Software Supply Chain Report 2019
problem: The state of software supply chain, current development practices and exemplary development practices
method: mining from libraries.io and developer survey
result: many many results
authors: Sonatype

title: The Emergence of Software Diversity in Maven Central
problem:
RQ1: To what extent are the different library versions actively used?
RQ2: How are the actively used versions distributed along the history of a library?
RQ3: Among the actively used versions of a library, is there one or several versions that are signi?cantly more popular than the others?
RQ4: Does the number of actively used versions relate to the popularity of a library? 
RQ5: How timely are the different library versions in Maven Central?
method: The Maven dependency graph dataset
result:
1. More than 40% of libraries have more than one actively used version.
2. The non-latest actively used versions are evenly distributed over time, and are usually previous major versions
3. 17% of the libraries have more than one significantly popular version.
4. Different versions are maintained for different purposes
5. No correlation between timeliness and popularity
authors: C¨¦sar Soto-Valero, Amine Benelallam, Nicolas Harrand, Olivier Barais, and Benoit Baudry

title: Small World with High Risks: A Study of Security Threats in the npm Ecosystem
An Empirical Comparison of Dependency Network Evolution in Seven Software Packaging System
What Do Package Dependencies Tell Us About Semantic Versioning?
problem: To what extent  are package maintainers following semantic versioning for their dependencies
method: Data from libraries.io - all major package managers involved
result: Maintainers generally trust semantic versioning policy now, but are often more permissive when using pre-1.0.0 libraries
authors: Alexandre Decan and Tom Mens

title: Dependency Versioning In the Wild
problem:
RQ1 How do projects declare dependencies? 
RQ2 Do projects change their approach as they evolve? 
RQ3 How do projects adapt semantic versioning?
method: Data from libraries.io - all major package managers involved
result:
RQ1: All package managers have flexible version declaration syntax, and have different preferences
RQ2: Fixed and flexible versioning strategies are both used, sometimes changed. One reason for change may be compatibility issues
RQ3: Semantic versioning is often suggested but not forced
authors: Jens Dietrich and David J. Pearce and Jacob Stringer and  Amjed Tahir and Kelly Blincoe

title: On the Diversity of Software Package Popularity Metrics: An Empirical Study of NPM
problem: How are metrics of package popularity related to each other?
method: correlation analysis of many metrics from different sources
result: Popularity can be measured with different metrics, each can be defined with in a specific context
authors: Ahmed Zerouali and Tom Mens and Gregorio Robles and Jesus Gonzalez-Barahona

title: Are Software Dependency Supply Chain Metrics Useful in Predicting Changes in Popularity of NPM Packages?
problem: Do the number and downloads of upstream and downstream dependencies help predict the downloads for popular JavaScript packages in NPM
method: time series analysis and linear regression and random forest models based on data from npm.io
result: The count and downloads of upstream and downstream dependencies have a strong effect on the change in downloads.
authors: Tapajit Dey and Audris Mockus

title: Do the Dependency Conflicts in My Project Matter?
On the Evolution of Technical Lags in the NPM Package Dependency Network
A Generalized Model for Visualizing Library Popularity, Adoption, and Diffusion within a Software Ecosystem
Structure and Evolution of Package Dependency Networks
problem:
RQ1: What are the static characterisitcs of package dependency networks?
RQ2: How do package dependency networks evolve?
RQ3: How vulnerable are package dependency networks to a removal of a random project?
method:
Data: libraries from npm, Cates and RubyGem + applications from GitHub
Network analysis on the dependency graph of versions
result:
1. these ecosystems are alive and growing
2. projects have more and more transitive dependencies
3. there are a subset of popular libraries used in most projects

title: An Empirical Comparison of Dependency Issues in OSS Packaging Ecosystems
On the Topology of Package Dependency Network
problem: Differences of dependency network
method: CRAN, NPM and PyPI
result: There are important differences in the three networks, thus its hard to generalize findings from one to another
authors: Alexandre Decan and Tom Men and Maelick Claes

title: A Look at the Dynamics of the JavaScript Package Ecosystem
problem:
1. the evolution of the npm ecosystem regarding growth and development activities
2.  assess the notion of package popularity in npm.
3. the creation of new package versions in npm, and the adoption of package versions by application developers.
method: Data: Official GitHub API and NPM API
result:
1. The npm is an active community
2. Different popularity measures are no substitute to another
3. package mangers use diversed versioning practices and the versioning itself doesnot indicate package maturity

title: Type Migration in Ultra-Large-Scale Code Bases
problem: How to scalably perform refactoring of one type to another
method:
Three step approach
1. Collecting type relevant language constructs
2. Detecting Refactorable Language Constructs 
3. Generating Refacterables
